the, uh, spectral sub- subtraction schemes a couple places did seem to- seem to do a nice job. And so, uh,|

for some processing to clean it up. It doesn't seem like it's that|

Uh, and there's this - I guess there's this mysterious - I mean people who do this a lot I guess have developed little tricks of the trade. I mean, there's -|

and you multiply this by a factor which is depend- dependent on the S_N_R.|

But when the power le- the s- signal level is|
uh small compared to the noise level, the coefficient is more important.|
And this reduce actually the music- musical noise, uh|
which is more important during silence portions, when|
So there are tricks like this but, mmm.|
Is the estimate of the noise spectrum a  running  estimate?|
Well, that's - I mean, that's what differs from different -|
different tasks and different s- uh, spectral subtraction methods. I mean, if -|
if you have, uh, fair assurance that, uh,|
the noise is - is quite stationary,|
then the smartest thing to do is use as much|
data as  possible  to estimate the noise, get a much better estimate, and subtract it off.|
But if it's varying at all, which is gonna be the case for almost any real situation, you have to|
do it on-line, uh, with some forgetting factor or something.|
So do you - is there some long window that extends into the past over which you calculate the average?|
Well, there's a lot of different ways of computing the noise spectrum. So one of the things|
that, uh, Hans-Guenter  Hirsch  did, uh - and pas- and other people - actually, he's - he wasn't the only one I guess,|
was to, uh, take some period of - of - of speech|
and in each band, uh, develop a histogram.|
So, to get a decent histogram of these energies|
takes at least a few seconds really. But, uh - I mean you can  do  it with a smaller amount but it's pretty rough.|
And, um, in  fact  I think the NIST|
standard method of determining signal-to-noise ratio is based on this.|
No, no, it's based on this kind of method, this histogram method.  So you have a  histogram.|
Now, if you have  signal  and you have  noise,  you basically have these two  bumps|
in the histogram, which you could approximate as two Gaussians.|
But wh- don't they overlap sometimes?|
So you have a mixture of two  Gaussians.|

Right? And you can use E_M to figure out what it  is.  You know. So - so basically now you have this mixture of two Gaussians, you - you n- know what they are, and, uh - I mean, sorry, you estimate what they are,|
and, uh, so this gives you what the signal is and what the  noise  e- energy is|
in that band in the  spectrum.  And then you look over the whole thing and now you have a noise spectrum.|
So, uh, Hans-Guenter  Hirsch  and others have used that kind of method. And the other thing to do|
is - which is sort of more trivial and obvious  - is to, uh,|
uh, determine through magical means that - that, uh, there's no speech in some period, and then see what the spectrum is.|
you know, it's - that - that - that's|
tricky to do. It has mistakes. Uh, and if you've got enough time, uh, this other method appears to be somewhat more reliable.|
Uh, a variant on that for just determining signal-to-noise ratio|

Don't worry about the variances. And then you just use those mean values as being the - the, uh|
it seems like this kind of thing could add to the latency.|
where the window was that you used to calculate  the signal-to-noise ratio.|

for example, um, he presents um,|
uh, a detector to detect sonorance.|
And so what - what it  basically  is - is, um - it's - there's -|
at the lowest level, there - it's - it's an  OR  ga- I mean, it's an  AND  gate. So, uh, on each sub-band you have several|
um, there's the existence of sonorance in a sub-band.|
And then, um, it c- it's combined by a soft AND gate.|
And at the - at the  higher  level,|
for every - if, um - The  higher  level there's a soft  OR  gate.|
Uh, so if - if this detector detects|
um, the presence of - of sonorance in any of the sub-bands, then the detect- uh, the  OR  gate at the top says, "O_K, well this frame|
has evidence of sonorance." And these are all -|
What are - what are some of the low level detectors that they use?|
Oh, O_K. Well, the low level detectors are logistic regressions.|
Um, and the, uh - the one o-|
So  that,  by the way, basically is a - is one of the units in our - in our - our neural network. So that's all it is. It's a sig- it's a sigmoid,|
uh, with weighted sum at the input,|
which you train by gradient  descent.|

to um train up these um parameters for the logistic regression.|

then he has each of these  AND  things. And, um,|
but - so they're little  neural  -  neural  units.|

And so are each of these, low level detectors  - are they, uh -|
are these something that you decide  ahead  of time, like "I'm going to look for this particular feature or I'm going to look at this frequency," or -|

and for - for every s- every sub-band,|
pick ahead of time, um, "I'm going to have like five|
to come up with your training targets for a - for the - the low-level detectors.|

and h- he shows that using this - this method to detect sonorance is-|

Gaussian mixtures um estimations of - of sonorance.|
so that's just - that's just one detector. So you can imagine|
building many of these detectors on different features. You get enough of these detectors together,|
um, then you have enough information to do, um, higher level discrimination, for example, discriminating between phones|
and then you keep working your way up until you - you build a full recognizer.|
So, um, that's - that's the direction|
which I'm - I'm thinking about going in my quals.|
You know, it has a number of properties that I really liked. I mean, one is the going towards, um,|
using narrow band information for, uh, ph- phonetic features of some sort rather than just, uh,|
immediately going for the - the typical sound units.|
Another thing I like about it is that you t- this thing is going to be trained -|
explicitly  trained for a product of errors rule,|
which is what, uh, Allen keeps pointing out that Fletcher observed in the twenties,|
uh, for  people  listening to narrow band stuff. That's Friday's talk, by the way.|
Uh, the  third  thing I like about it is,|
uh, and we've played around with this in a different kind of way a  little  bit but it hasn't been our dominant way of - of operating anything,|
um, this issue of where the targets come from.|

is, uh, that we get the phonetic label -|
for the  sound  there and we say, "O_K, we train every -"  What  this  is saying is, O_K, that's maybe what our  ultimate  goal is - or not ultimate but|
